newsitem.title: USA: Apple says Ellen Hancock not leaving.
newsitem.headline: Apple says Ellen Hancock not leaving.

text.p: Apple Computer Inc., squelching speculation in trade magazines, said Friday its chief technical officer, Ellen Hancock, does not plan to leave the company.
"We did in fact speak with her at (the) MacWorld (trade show) in Tokyo and she said she has no plans to leave," said Apple spokeswoman Katie Cotton.

On Thursday, the online version of trade magazine PC Week reported that Hancock -- who oversees Apple's research and development -- was negotiating a severance package in preparation for handing in her resignation. It cited unidentified sources.
Hancock, who was still in Japan, could not be reached for comment.
Since a horde of key executives began leaving Apple three weeks ago, speculation has swirled about who in the executive suite would leave next.

Hancock has been a favourite candidate, analysts said, because Chairman Gilbert Amelio recently took over her chief responsibility -- overseeing an effort to revamp the fundamental software of the Macintosh by merging it with software technology from recently purchased Next Software Inc.
Hancock has said she has been unhappy about losing the role, but said she understands Amelio's decision and would work with him.
On Tuesday, Marco Landi, the well-regarded executive vice president of sales, resigned.
The week before, Heidi Roizen, the liaison between Apple and software companies, quit.
Satjiv Chahil -- the marketing executive who got Hollywood to give starring roles to Apple's portable computers in last summer's blockbusters -- also left last week.

With Landi's resignation, none of Apple's top executives -- Hancock, Amelio, Chief Financial Officer Fred Anderson and Chief Administrative Officer George Scalise -- has been at Apple for more than 13 months. They joined Apple shortly after Amelio replaced Michael Spindler as CEO in February 1996.
